awd_titl_txt: Observations to Constrain the Origins of Hot Gas Between Galaxies and Clusters of Galaxies Across Cosmic Time
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the question of why galaxies look the way they do throughout the history of our universe.  It will focus on the warm/hot gas that surrounds galaxies and provides them with fuel to form new stars. There is only incomplete theoretical understanding of the physical processes within galaxies that heat and alter this surrounding gas. This project will measure the imprint of this gas on leftover photons from the big bang which will provide new and critical information on the physics of these processes. This project will also run a pilot program to spark the interests of preschoolers in astronomy at two Agri-Business Child Development (ABCD) centers. The ABCD program offers comprehensive early childhood education to low-income families where both parents are agriculturally employed.   
  
This project will constrain feedback processes in galaxies using cross-correlation measurements from large-scale structure surveys and cosmic microwave background (CMB) experiments. Feedback processes play an important role in theories of galaxy formation and evolution. They are thought to regulate star formation in galaxies and affect the large-scale distribution of matter in our universe. An essential aspect of feedback not well understood is its impact on the reservoirs of warm/hot ionized gas that surrounds galaxies, the circumgalactic medium (CGM), which provides galaxies with new or recycled material to form new generations of stars. This project uses observations of additional fluctuations in the CMB (specifically the Sunyaev-Zeldovich effects) to probe the thermodynamic history of the CGM and provide essential information on the role of feedback in galaxy formation and evolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Principle investigator Dr. Nicholas Battaglia and collaborators, Dr. Stefania Amodeo, Dr. Simone Ferraro, Dr. Emmanuel Schaan, and Dr. Emily Moser completed their work on the NSF funded grant “Observations to Constrain the Origins of Hot Gas Between Galaxies and Clusters of Galaxies Across Cosmic Time.” As a result this work, the team has further our understanding of the hot gas in and around massive galaxies when the Universe was approximately 8 billion years old. This gas is the reservoir of material that provides the fuel for new stars to form within galaxies, thus study it gives us clues as to how galaxies evolve over time. 

In order to study the gas around galaxies, this work used measurements the most ancient light in the Universe,  the cosmic micro background (CMB), which is is leftover light (photons) from the Big Bang. As these photon traveled through our Universe to us, some of them interacted with the gas around galaxies that are between us and CMB. Using statistical methods we measured the unique signatures of these interactions of CMB photons with the galaxy gas and were able to extract properties like the density and temperature of this gas. The CMB observations came from the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) and the Planck satellite and the galaxy sample was provided by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). The measurements made in this work are the highest fidelity measurements of gas in and around massive galaxies using the CMB. With these measurements in hand we were able to further our understanding of how galaxy evolve.

With respect to galaxy evolution, we have provided constraints on the gas properties from within galaxies extending out into the IGM. These constraints have found an issue with current numerical simulations of galaxy evolution as the simulations do not match our constraints. The difference between our measurements and simulations have persisted even after modified our analyses pipelines, changed simulation parameters, and thoroughly tested our analyses and inference pipelines. We also showed how future measurements will be more restrictive (or informative) to numerical simulations.

Additionally with our measurement we were able to impact the field of cosmology. Here, we provide measurements and methods to empirically calibrate the impact of baryons on the matter power spectrum on small spatial scales. These calibrations can be used push the current observational limits to smaller spatial scales and extract more cosmological information. How baryons affect the matter power spectrum is an important systematic modeling uncertainty that cosmologists need to understand in order to push future cosmological observations to their full potential.

Dr. Emily Moser received her PhD working on this award. This work represents just the begin of such studies and the PI will continue to work further on these measurements and analyses as new data from current and future CMB experiments and galaxy surveys become available.

As part of the broader impacts of this award the PI Dr. Nicholas Battaglia started a pilot outreach project with nearby Agri-Business Child Development (ABCD) schools (Seneca falls and Geneva about an hour outside of Ithaca). There Dr. Battaglia ran astronomy related activities for preschoolers, 3-5 year-olds, once a month for 30 minutes per class. The goal was to expose these children, who are predominantly minorities and at or below the poverty line, to STEM activities that would not get to do otherwise. This program ran from Sept. 2019 until the end of the award (with a small break due to COVID) and there are ongoing efforts to continue this project beyond this proposal.
